understanding the freebie debate here
you need to understand two schools of
Economics the first school of thought is
rooted in capitalism which says that
every individual in the economy should
earn based on their Merit and
contribution according to this view the
government has no business handing out
free money because it disrupts the
natural flow of economic productivity
this view says that in a fair system
those who create value Excel and they
earn their rewards while those who fail
to stay relevant face the consequences
even if it means poverty and it also
says that providing free money not only
drains the state's resources but also
undermines the efforts of hardworking
individuals who earn their livelihood
through dedication and skill and it says
that handing out free money is not
justified because it shifts the burden
onto the productive members of the
society which creates an imbalance and
discourages Innovation and hard work
whereas if you look at the other school
of thought the other school of thought
argues that true economic growth can
only occur when the bottom of the
pyramid is uplifted this perspective
emphasizes that providing essential
Necessities like water and electricity
can unlock productivity and economic
potential for example if a factory
worker cannot afford clean water his
wife might spend hours fetching it from
a distant well instead of contributing
to the Workforce Now imagine if 1
million women waste their time fetching
water we are practically removing 1
million potential workers from the
economy however with access to free
water these women can join the workforce
and produce output for the factories and
these factories can then generate
revenue and pay taxes to the government
similarly if a household has two earning
members their children are more like to
attend better schools and gain better
skills to become future professionals
who then go on to contribute to the
economy this approach is known as the
bottom up approach which believes in
empowering people with the most
essential resources to help them focus
on work education and productivity now
if you look at the Amad party this
bottomup approach is exactly what
they've been pursuing they give out free
electricity up to 200 units free water
up to 20,000 L free education and even
give people free health care with the
moala clinics this strategy not only
addresses the immediate hardships but
also creates a ripple effect that

free electricity and water reduce

to invest in better opportunities for
their children free education provides

the next generation is equipped with the

to the workforce and lastly free

fiscal Surplus happens when the
government has extra money left after
covering all of its regular expenses
like salaries subsidies administrative
costs and other expenditures and look at
